page.title: 16MINING..CHANGE
page.content: Prior to the advent of coal mining, Kelty was predominantly rural. There were several small pits operating in the area but towards the end of the 19th Century three fairly large pits were sunk. These were the Lindsay, 1896, right on the outskirts of the village. Another two were, the Aitken, 1893 and Lumphinans no. 11, 1896. Both these two pits were within a mile of the village. The population, by 1912, had risen to nearly 9,000. All the pits in the area are now closed and the village has a population of just over 5,000. Kelty has suffered adversely with the closure of the local pits because there has been very little alternative employment provided.
